15.text: So, last month, the Encyclopaedia Britannica announced

19.text: that it is going out of print

21.text: after 244 years, which made me nostalgic,

24.text: because I remember playing a game with the colossal encyclopedia set in my hometown library

30.text: back when I was a kid,

33.text: And I wondered if I could update that game,

40.text: I went to an online encyclopedia,

41.text: Wikipedia, and I entered the term "Earth."

44.text: You can start anywhere, this time I chose Earth.

47.text: And the first rule of the game is pretty simple.

49.text: You just have to read the article

51.text: until you find something you don't know,

53.text: and preferably something your dad doesn't even know.

56.text: And in this case, I quickly found this:

59.text: The furthest point from the center of the Earth

62.text: is not the tip of Mount Everest, like I might have thought,

64.text: it's the tip of this mountain: Mount Chimborazo in Ecuador.

67.text: The Earth spins, of course, as it travels around the sun,

71.text: so the Earth bulges a little bit around the middle,

74.text: And even though Mount Chimborazo isn't the tallest mountain in the Andes,

79.text: it's one degree away from the equator,

81.text: it's riding that bulge, and so the summit of Chimborazo

84.text: is the farthest point on Earth from the center of the Earth.

87.text: And it is really fun to say.

91.text: this is going to be the name of the game,

103.text: So the next rule of the game is also pretty simple.

107.text: You just have to find another term and look that up.

115.text: Nowadays there are hundreds of links to choose from.

124.text: That took me to this wet and warm band of the tropics

131.text: Now that's the Tropic of Cancer in the north

133.text: and the Tropic of Capricorn in the south,

136.text: but I was surprised to learn this little fact:

140.text: like latitude or the borders between nations,

144.text: they are astronomical phenomena caused by the Earth's tilt,

148.text: They move; they go up, they go down.

151.text: In fact, for years, the Tropic of Cancer and the Tropic of Capricorn

154.text: have been steadily drifting towards the equator

156.text: at the rate of about 15 meters per year,

162.text: So to keep the game going, I just have to find another term and look that one up.

168.text: Since I'm already in the tropics, I chose "Tropical rainforest."

172.text: Famous for its diversity, human diversity.

174.text: There are still dozens and dozens of uncontacted tribes living on this planet.

180.text: They're all over the globe, but virtually all of them live in tropical rainforests.

184.text: This is the only place you can go nowadays and not get "friended."

198.text: It mentioned leopards and ring-tailed coatis and poison dart frogs and boa constrictors and then

207.text: which turn out to be beetles.

220.text: This is the most successful order on the planet by far.

224.text: Something between 20 and 25 percent of all life forms on the planet,

230.text: That means the next time you are in the grocery store,

232.text: take a look at the four people ahead of you in line.

235.text: Statistically, one of you is a beetle.

238.text: And if it is you, you are astonishingly well adapted.

243.text: There are scavenger beetles that pick the skin and flesh off of bones in museums.

248.text: There are predator beetles, that attack other insects

251.text: and still look pretty cute to us.

253.text: There are beetles that roll little balls of dung

257.text: great distances across the desert floor to feed to their hatchlings.

260.text: This reminded the ancient Egyptians of their god Khepri,

264.text: who renews the ball of the sun every morning,

267.text: which is how that dung-rolling scarab

269.text: became that sacred scarab on the breastplate of the Pharaoh Tutankhamun.

274.text: Beetles, I was reminded, have the most romantic flirtation in the animal kingdom.

280.text: Fireflies are not flies, fireflies are beetles.

283.text: Fireflies are coleoptera, and coleoptera communicate in other ways as well.

407.text: The back of the hand is formally called the opisthenar.

411.text: Now that's embarrassing, because up until now,

415.text: every time I've said, "I know it like the back of my hand,"

418.text: I've really been saying, "I'm totally familiar with that,

431.text: I click on chimpanzee, and I get our closest genetic relative.

435.text: Pan troglodytes, the name we give him, means "cave dweller."

441.text: He lives in rainforests and savannas.

442.text: It's just that we're always thinking of this guy as lagging behind us,

446.text: evolutionarily or somehow uncannily creeping up on us,

449.text: and in some cases, he gets places before us.

452.text: Like my next link, the almost irresistible link, Ham the Astrochimp.

463.text: which is smack in the middle of my tropics map,

473.text: In between those two landmarks in Ham's life,

482.text: months before the first human being to do it,

487.text: When I click on Yuri Gagarin's page,

489.text: I get this guy who was surprisingly short in stature,

494.text: Top estimates, Soviet estimates, put this guy at 1.65 meters,

498.text: that is less than five and a half feet tall max,

501.text: possibly because he was malnourished as a child.

506.text: A Nazi officer took over the Gagarin household,

510.text: and he and his family built and lived in a mud hut.

512.text: Years later, the boy from that cramped mud hut

516.text: would grow up to be the man in that cramped capsule

519.text: on the tip of a rocket

521.text: who volunteered to be launched into outer space,

525.text: the first one of any of us to really physically leave this planet.

529.text: And he didn't just leave it,

533.text: Fifty years later, as a tribute,

535.text: the International Space Station, which is still up there tonight,

539.text: synced its orbit with Gagarin's orbit,

543.text: at the exact same time of day,

546.text: so you can go online and you can watch over 100 minutes

549.text: of what must have been an absolutely mesmerizing ride,

554.text: the first person to ever see such a thing.

556.text: And then when you've had your fill of that,

558.text: you can click on one more link.

560.text: You can come back to Earth.

562.text: You return to where you started.

566.text: You just need to find one more fact that you didn't know.

570.text: And for me, I quickly landed on this one:

572.text: The Earth has a tolerance of about .17 percent from the reference spheroid,

577.text: which is less than the .22 percent allowed in billiard balls.

581.text: This is the kind of fact I would have loved as a boy.

585.text: It's got some math that I can do.

587.text: I'm pretty sure my dad doesn't know it.

589.text: What this means is that if you could shrink the Earth to the size of a billiard ball,

595.text: if you could take planet Earth, with all its mountain tops and caves

601.text: and rainforests, astronauts and uncontacted tribes and chimpanzees, voodoo dolls,

605.text: fireflies, chocolate, sea creatures making love in the deep blue sea,

611.text: you just shrink that to the size of a billiard ball,

614.text: it would be as smooth as a billiard ball,

618.text: presumably a billiard ball with a slight bulge around the middle.
